metadata.name: HASH*W1NDOWS #67
metadata.description:
HASH*W1NDOWS made in PICO-8. 
Window tribute to John Karel by Y Griega.

Features:
51 Elements(6 rare).
32 Base Colours (4 layers)
12 Background Textures (3 layers).
4 Window views.

Rare Features:
+ Dark Palette (warm)
+ Death Palette (negative)
+  Fx (flys, glitch, etc...)
--twitter.com/YGriegaMX

metadata.name: Umbra #197
metadata.description: A generative series of shadows cast by simple geometric shapes.

metadata.name: Brosser #248
metadata.description:
Exploring generative brush strokes to simulate real life paintings. 

- A selection of 19 different palettes
- 4 different drawing styles
- Randomized "color swap" between the primary and secondary colors in each palette

Several other factors determine the output of a piece, including angles, depth, brush length, and brush weight, among others.

metadata.name: RGB Elementary Cellular Automaton #910
metadata.description:
Stephen Wolfram's Elementary Cellular Automaton where 3 different rules are drawn in the Red, Green and Blue color components of the image.

Rules are selected randomly among a pre-selection of 53 rules from which nice behaviors emerge.

Tokens can have a cell size in the [1; 20] range.

metadata.name: Fischbach #197
metadata.description:
#fxhashturnsone

The first 365 crazy days of fxhash - time to celebrate this and take a look back.

The entropy of memories in a vivid photo collage that gives me goosebumps while others might just see moving eye candy. Perspective and perception can be so different.

Based on some of my photos from the last 365 days that trigger emotional memories, even if they are not directly connected. By the way, Fischbach is the name of the small village where I grew up. It was a great time!

How does it work?

Each piece uses pairs of photos and colors (top/bottom).

The animated collage itself is based on two layers. The first layer uses a double buffer to cut, colorize and animate the photos. The second layer is mainly just for screen rendering, debugging and behind-the-scene looks.

Cutting and pasting photos is based on a variable moving color grid, the fixed horizon, the variable position of the photos top/bottom, the previous buffer and some magic distance calculations between them.

The grid itself is a combination of vertical color stripes with variable position and distance factors that determine the color gradient between the two colors, and folds that alternate between the two colors depending on the horizontal and vertical values.

Especially the entropy of the photos and the colored grid influence the pixel movement.

Animation changes are triggered after a random number of frames and effect folds, stripes and photo position. These replace parts of the current collage (fade to black) or add some (discard fragment updates).

Features:

- top color [12] - hue, colorful & bright
- bottom color [6] - hue, less colorful & bright
- top photo [16] (zingst, birds, xmas, zustand, zebra, moving-blocks-mono, fischbach, santanyi, goldblume, ♠4, driften, brand-pyramide, zäpfle, bc, tisa, lieblingspulli)
- bottom photo: [16] (zingst, birds, xmas, zustand, zebra, moving-blocks-mono, fischbach, santanyi, goldblume, ♠4, driften, brand-pyramide, zäpfle, bc, tisa, lieblingspulli)
- horizon [0.618, 0.5, 0.382] (down, center, up)
- hectic [3, 5, 11] (calm, slightly, very)
- horizontal folds [113, 365, 997, 2153, 3987] - used for first animation iteration, variable
- vertical folds [7, 37, 127, 571, 1501, 3147] - used for first animation iteration, variable
- min stripes [1, 3, 5] - used for first animation iteration, variable

Animation and feature selection are based on the deterministic prng Xoshiro128 seeded with the fxhash. This allows repeated playback in the same sequence. The animation is synchronized with frames and not with time.

The preview images are taken after 300 frames.

Shortcuts & interactions:

- spacebar, mouse click or tap touch to trigger animation changes
- `c` to take a picture
- `f` for full screen mode
- `p` to pause
- `h` to see all options

Available query string parameters:

- autopause - enable automatic pausing
- pixelratio=2 - sets the pixel ratio (default: device)
- showannouncement - activates the announcement
- kioskspeed=10 - activates the kiosk mode and sets the speed in seconds
- showinfo - activates the info box

metadata.name: FHX-1 #231
metadata.description:
• #fxhashturnsone •

All primary proceeds are donated to The Processing Foundation and Girls Who Code.
https://processingfoundation.org
https://girlswhocode.com/about-us


Controls:
[s] save as PNG.


Notes:
Artworks take a few seconds to render.

I generated the raw base unprocessed GAN seeds used in this piece offline from various custom styleGAN models. All the mixing and processing steps are done generatively online in p5.js by the FHX algorithm.


⫸ GAN ⫸ p5.js ⫸ Blockchain


Copyright (©) 2022 Thomas Noya

◉_◉

metadata.description:
Exploring generative brush strokes to simulate real life paintings. 

- A selection of 19 different palettes
- 4 different drawing styles
- Randomized "color swap" between the primary and secondary colors in each palette

Several other factors determine the output of a piece, including angles, depth, brush length, and brush weight, among others.

metadata.name: Doors of Perception #1
metadata.description:
The title of this work is inspired by Aldous Huxley's book of the same name, exploring ideas of conciousness.

Inspiration is found in the places we choose to look. I have been personally motivated to learn p5js from scratch, to be able to mint this, my very first generative artwork. This motivation came from seeing the work of others right here on fxhash.

Aldous Huxley himself took the title for his book from the William Blake poem 'The Marriage of Heaven and Hell';

“If the doors of perception were cleansed every thing would appear to man as it is: Infinite. For man has closed himself up, till he sees all things thro' narrow chinks of his cavern”

I hope my work inspires you in some small way.

Whilst each mint will be infinitely unique, there are no intentional rarity traits. Variations are made in door count, frame split, colours, and speed.

Press 's' to save .png

metadata.name: Casuariiformes #92
metadata.description:
Casuariiformes are beautiful and colorful birds that give name to this project.

The intent of the project is to use geometry and colors to create beautiful compositions. Even in its own chaos, they primary shapes create a balance that make the composition appealing to human eye.

Note: if you get all six dice faces without repetition, DM me on Twitter as you will get a special airdrop!
